body.p: The ∏ environment can be easily customized to suit your system configuration, work process, and aesthetic tastes. Most of this is handled via the Settings Tool.

Any changes you make to your development image are saved along with the image. You can also export your customized settings as an XML file, to easily reproduce all of your customizations when installing a new release of the environment.

system settingsSettings ToolThe Settings Tool allows you to control a variety of global parameters, including the appearance of windows, source file name, and the default font for text. To open the Settings Tool, choose System &arrow; Settings in the ∏ Launcher window.

p.xref: Open the Settings Tool for me

body.p: Use the scroll buttons and tabs on the right-hand side of the Settings window to navigate among its pages.

topic.title: Set the Home Directory for an Image

body.p: home directorydirectoryhomeimageset home directoryTo set the default "home" directory for the current image, select File → Set ∏ Home... in the Launcher window. The Settings Tool opens to the System page, on which you should enter the path to the directory that contains the current ∏ installation.
As a short-cut, you can click the Paste Current button, which enters the current installation directory. Usually, this is the correct directory.
Once the directory has been specified, select Apply or OK.

The ∏ home directory path may be referenced using the parameter $(VISUALWORKS). This parameter is used to locate the system sources and changes file, as well as parcels that can be loaded. Make sure you supply the name of the main installation directory, of which /image, /parcels, and /bin are sub-directories.

topic.title: Set the Look and Feel of the User Interface

body.p: On the Look and Feel page of the Settings Tool, use the Skin menu to change the appearance and behavior of buttons, scroll bars, and other widgets.

The Native skin uses native drawing to provide a high-fidelity, native look for platforms that support it. For platforms that do not have a true "native" look (e.g., X11), the Native skin is replaced by a Default skin, which provides a platform-agnostic look. The Default skin is available on any platform.
The new look and feel will apply to any window that you open subsequently.

When the Ignore action button double clicks setting is disabled (this is the default), rapid clicks on action buttons are recognized as separate clicks, no matter how quickly the button is clicked. When the option is enabled, they are considered to be double clicks and in effect ignored.

When the Open dialog boxes centered at mouse cursor is disabled (this is the default), dialog boxes open centered inside the currently-active window, or inside the screen if there is no current window. When this setting is enabled, dialog boxes open centered at the mouse cursor.
textset global text attributesThe default theme, text style and size used in the ∏ Source Code Editor may be set from the Editor page of the Settings Tool.

∏ also keeps a set of global text attributes which you may adjust on the Tools page of the Settings Tool. To change the attributes used to render text, select one of the following: Small This will select text that is slightly smaller than "default", useful for small displays on the order of 640x480 pixels Default The usual style, suitable for 1024x768 displays Large A slightly larger style, for 1600x1280 hi-res displays Fixed Similar to "default", but all characters are the same size — this is useful for presenting table-oriented data or in a terminal emulator
To redefine the default text attributes press the corresponding radio button, and select Accept.
On the Look and Feel page of the Settings Tool, click the Key Bindings &arrow; Edit... button to open the Key Bindings Editor.

The Key Bindings Editor allows you to explore and edit the key bindings for commands. Note that the key bindings are not saved with the preferences. You can save and load key bindings from the editor window.

internationalizationenable globalizationOn the UI Options page of the Settings Tool, use the Show UI for Globalization setting to enable fields for support of globalization. When this option is enabled, the GUI Painter Tool will show special fields such as keys for message catalogs.

window placement optionsOn the Look and Feel page of the Settings Tool, use the Window placement setting to specify whether newly-created windows are positioned on the screen by the user or are automatically positioned under the current mouse position with a default size.

mouse button optionsOn the Look and Feel page of the Settings Tool, use the Mouse button order setting to specify which mouse buttons perform which functions. The first option binds the right mouse button to the <Operate> menu of the current view, while the middle button opens the <Window> menu. The second option swaps the roles of the middle and the right buttons.

The second option is the traditional Smalltalk-80 button configuration (also known as red, yellow, blue). The first option, however, is the default because it works better with two-button mice. For those, the <Window> function becomes unassigned while the right button remains bound to the more frequently used <Operate> menu.

topic.title: Set a Limit on the Length of Icon Labels

body.p: iconlimit label lengthOn the Tools page of the Settings Tool, adjust the Icon Label Length setting to constrain the length of icon label text.

topic.title: Specify the Use of Native File Dialogs

body.p: On the Tools page of the Settings Tool, toggle the Use native file dialogs setting to enable (this is the default) or disable the use of platform file dialogs to prompt for the names of files to open or save.
When this setting is disabled, portable ∏ dialogs are used.
printingset printing optionsSelect the Printing page of the Settings Tool.

Use the Document Printing options to choose between PostScript and Host printer drivers (the latter are supported only on MS-Windows platforms). If Host Printing is selected on a non-Windows platform, the system will default back to PostScript at print time.

Use the Text Printing options to choose how hardcopy commands (i.e., in browser code views) are handled. To make hardcopies via the Document system, select Document Printing; to save hardcopy as a disk file (named temp.prt by default), select Plain Text Printing.
browsingset optionsSelect the Browsing page in the Settings Tool.

To control the default action of the Browse &arrow; Class Named... command in the Launcher window, use the Class Browsing setting. To open a hierarchy browser on the specified class, all of its subclasses and superclasses, select Use Hierarchy Browsers; to open a class browser on the specified class, select Use Class Browsers.

To change display options for the System Browser, change the Show Namespaces, Show Parcels, and Show Packages switches. Enabling these options will add multi-fuction tabs and additional menu options to the System Browser. These options also affect the evaluation of the browse message (e.g., Collection browse.)
filesset source filesfilesset changes filessource fileschange filesSelect the Source &arrow; Source Files option in the Settings Tool to change the name of the system sources or changes files.

By default, both the sources ".sou" and changes ".cha" files reside in the /image directory. In a networked environment, users normally share the same sources file and have a private changes file. To establish such a configuration, either add a new sources file path and click on Accept; or else select an existing source file from the scrollable list, edit the field below the list to contain the absolute path name of the shared sources file, and click on the Change button.
To keep the changes file in a location other than the startup directory, select changes file ".cha", and insert the appropriate path and file name.
When you make a backup copy of a ∏ image, three files must be archived together: the image file, the sources file, and the changes file.
source directoriesdirectoriesset source directoriesSelect the Source Dirs option in the Settings Tool to change the directories where system and parcel source files are located.

To add a new sources path, enter the path in the field below the scrollable list and click on Accept. To modify an existing path, select it in the scrollable list, edit the field, and click on Change.
parcelsset load optionsSelect the Parcel Path page in the Settings Tool to set parcel loading options.

To reference the ∏ home directory, use the parameter $(VISUALWORKS). If a parcel has prerequisite parcels, they will be searched for in the directories and in the order specified in this list. The period character "." is used to indicate the directory in which the current parcel is being loaded from, not the directory in which ∏ is running. Use "." to search for a parcel’s prerequisites in the same directory as the parcel.
internationalizationset message catalogsUse the Messages page of the Settings Tool to specify directories containing message catalogs for internationalization.

The list view specifies which directories contain message catalog files. These directories contain a collection of subdirectories, where each subdirectory is given a name that identifies the language group for which it is intended. Message catalog files for specific languages are located in these subdirectories.

To add a directory, type the directory’s name into the input field, and press the Add button. To delete a directory, select it in the list and press Delete. To change a directory, select it in the list, change the name which appears in the input field, and then press Change.
Use Accept to finalize, and Reset to revert your changes.

topic.title: Set XML Source Code Option for File-outs

body.p: source codeformat optionsUse the File-out Type page of the Settings Tool to specify use of XML formatting for source code files saved with File Out.
By default, sources are stored using XML. For compatibility with versions prior to ∏ 5i, set this option to Smalltalk chunk source code.
